# Timeline of Montana history

This timeline is a chronology of significant events in the history of the U.S. State of Montana and the historical area now occupied by the state.
__NOTOC__
2020s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2024||align=center|November 5||The 2024 General Election will be held on November 5, 2024.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2022||align=center|November 8||In the 2022 general election, Montana voters elect Ryan Zinke as the U.S. representative for the new 1st congressional district and U.S. representative at-large Matt Rosendale for the new 2nd Congressional District. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2020||align=center|November 3||In the 2020 General Election, Montana voters elect three presidential electors for Donald Trump, re-elect Steve Daines as junior U.S. Senator, elect Matt Rosendale as U.S. representative at-large, and elect Greg Gianforte as Governor. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 2020 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Montana, later determined to be 1,084,225, an increase of 9.58% since the 2010 United States census. Montana remains the 44th most populous of the 50 U.S. states, but will gain a second Congressional seat.
|}
2010s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-

|-
|align=center|January 7||Governor Steve Bullock announces his candidacy for President of the United States.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2018||align=center|December 15||Ryan Zinke resigns as United States Secretary of the Interior following congressional investigations.
|-
|align=center|November 6||In the 2018 General Election, Montana voters re-elect Jon Tester as senior U.S. Senator and elect Greg Gianforte as U.S. representative at-large. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center|October 18||At a political rally in Missoula, U.S. President Donald Trump congratulates Congressman Greg Gianforte for his assault of reporter Ben Jacobs.
|-

|-
|align=center|May 24||Congressional candidate Greg Gianforte assaults reporter Ben Jacobs.
|-
|align=center|March 1||U.S. representative at-large Ryan Zinke is confirmed and assumes office as United States Secretary of the Interior.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2016||align=center|November 8||In the 2016 general election, Montana voters elect three presidential electors for Donald Trump, re-elect Ryan Zinke as U.S. representative at-large, and re-elect Steve Bullock as Governor. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2015||align=center|January 3||Steve Daines assumes office as the junior United States senator for the State of Montana.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2014||align=center|November 4||In the 2014 General Election, Montana voters elect Steve Daines as junior U.S. Senator and elect Ryan Zinke as U.S. representative at-large. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2013||align=center|January 7||Steve Bullock assumes office as the 24th governor of the State of Montana.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2012||align=center|November 6||In the 2012 general election, Montana voters elect three presidential electors for Mitt Romney, re-elect Jon Tester as senior U.S. Senator, elect Steve Daines as U.S. representative at-large, and elect Steve Bullock as governor. Republicans retain control of the Montana Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2010||align=center|November 2||In the 2010 general election, Montana voters re-elect Denny Rehberg as U.S. representative at-large. Republicans retain control of the Montana Senate and regain control of the Montana House of Representatives.
|-
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 2010 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Montana, later determined to be 989,415, an increase of 9.7% since the 2000 United States census. Montana remains the 44th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}

!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event

The Nez Perce National Historical Park now includes the Big Hole National Battlefield and the Bear Paw Battlefield in Montana.
|-

|-
